Ladies and gentlemen, I present to you

The New Camera.

She's a Canon EOS 40D which is an incredible step up from my old 300D, she shoots 10.1 megapixels at 6.5 frames per second and can do ISO speeds up to 3200 with incredible noise reduction compared to what I'm used to.

Its almost a crime to use my crappy lenses on it, but that'll be fixed soon enough.

So there it is, expect better photos tomorrow I was just dicking around in my apartment when I took this one.

title: Faces
description:
The one thing that has struck me the most out of anything while going through the pictures from my journey were the faces. These kids loved having their picture taken. Loved it. My fellow photographer Charlie and I always joked, "you can take as many pictures of the kids as you want, as long as you show them every single one." It was true, there's some incredible allure to seeing yourself frozen in time on a tiny screen.

The next few pictures (as I get to them) are portraits of second or third generation Hatian refugees. Some of them knew I was taking their picture, others don't. To me, at least, these photos carry such emotion and meaning. Many are even hard to look at.

An interesting note. The children only put on the stern or uncomfortable faces when my lens was pointed at them. At all other times their smiles were huge. The only way I ever got pictures of smiling children was when they didn't know I was taking their picture.


These boys and a few others had just put on an amazing show of acrobatics for us. They could all do flawless cartwheels, and a couple could do... I think they're called handsprings? or backsprings? I'm not sure. It was really impressive though.

title: Ever Watchful
description:
A rock formation in Baharona where we're staying.
                Our fearless leader/host/translator/worksite supervisor/tour guide wanted a picture
                because his camera can't take it well. He believes that this rock formation
                (supposedly carved by native people before the Spanish arrived) would boost tourism
                in the area, and bring more money in. I really do hope it works, because this is one
                of the most beautiful countries I've ever had the pleasure of seeing, and
                if more people saw the poverty here, I think there'd be much more action
                about it.

title: Touchdown
description:
Every time the plane banked a little too hard I prayed for a crash, or a midair collision...

So talking to the other peeps, it seems like I might have internet access in the DR, so you might be getting consistent updates (if you're really interested). We ran into two other groups, World Servants and Orphanage Outreach who are also going to the Dominican Republic, I wonder if that flight is always full of missionaries, there's only one flight from the US into the DR each week so it probably is. In any case, I haven't even gotten out of the country yet and I already miss her <3

Talk to you later.

title: Bus
description:
A car themed deviation to commemorate my first car accident.

Some kid who just got his license was trying to weave around me while I was backing up. I got a little dent and some scratches on the very corner of my bumper, his headlight and rearview mirror went flying and he can't open any of his doors on that side anymore

I actually wasn't even sure I'd hit him until I went out to check, because my truck is so beastly his sedan couldn't even move it a noticeable amount.

I took a whole ton of pictures (What? I'm a photographer I'm allowed). They're here if you're curious [link] I was the white truck.

title: Jump Right In
description:
I am drifting, my only anchor your words through the telephone. It is far from now yet we are still young in spirit. We drive in silence down the road. Your legs rest in the open window, and you look to the beach so brilliant with sunset. Your hair moves in graceful waves around your face. You turn and look to me, and your sweet voice sings, "hello?" The clarity of the vision vanishes, like a memory or a song.

"Sorry, I think I fell asleep on the phone again. I love you.".

~SubstituteSadist <3

title: Red, You're Dead
description:
Which wire will you cut?

So I decided to try Lightroom because it seemed like it could be an extremely useful tool.

Wrong!

Its fantastic for editing photos, it pretty much lets you do to a JPEG what you'd normally have to have a RAW for. And then some. But when it comes down to it, its actually totally useless. It doesn't even allow you to save your changes back to the original file (say, for instance, if you wanted to upload it to a website) without having to go through several unnecessary steps. And it took several minutes of googleing to even figure out how to do that.

Never again, blech.

title: Perfect
description:
Do you remember? When watching those old documentary videos in school. The directors would cut to some bland stock footage of a bird flying, or a river flowing, or a flower swaying in the wind. Some time lapse of traffic or clouds or sunsets or plants growing. They would set the scene with a fleeting glance of a developing skyline or critters on the forest floor. These scenes were a way to artificially lengthen the film, without having to pay for actors or voice overs. They were unwanted, unnecessary, and unloved.

They were the scenes that I liked best.

title: New Life
description:
In the past few months, the San Fernando Valley has experienced several devastating fires. One of my favorite places to go rock climbing and hiking as a kid, Stoney Point, was hit very hard because of all the dry brush and trees there. This is a place that was literally burned all to hell, and damaged beyond recognition.

But not beyond repair.

New life is sprouting up all over the place, most of it is coming directly from the bases of burnt plants. Its a sight to see.

title: Spearhead
description:
So I've been seeing some of my better pictures being uploaded to various wallpaper sites and imageboards. This is cool and all, I like to see my work getting around, but I'd like to get some recognition out of it (being as egocentric as I am).

In this vein, I'm thinking about adding those annoying little copyright notices somewhere on my image. Watermarks are obviously out of the question because they make my picture look like shit and indicate extraordinary dickery, so that leaves boarders and such.

I like the simplicity of a single little strip off to the side, but I'd like your thoughts. Yay? Nay?

Putting them on is extra work for me, but if it brings more views to my DA without degrading the quality of my image it's something I'm down for. (Taking the pictures is easy enough anyway, whats a couple extra seconds in photoshop )

Opinions go!

title: The Approach
description:
Ladies and gentlemen of DeviantArt, I think I'm in love.

There's a place down the street from where I live that has a magnificent view of the mountains on the west side of the valley, and the sky above them. A lot of my sky/sunset pictures (most of the ones without a big palm tree in them) come from there.

So today, I'm driving home admiring the sunset fireworks and thinking about dropping by. I turn the corner and start driving up the hill to the spot (it's on my way home anyway) and I notice someone standing very still there.

I'm thinking why they could be there, there's no real reason to go there unless...

Then she turns around and she's holding Nikon D80 with this gigantic telephoto lens and an even larger hood.



So apparently she lives around here and saw me taking pictures there on her way someplace and thought it'd be a good idea. I'M AN INSPIRATION TO OTHERS!

LEVEL UP! +2 AWESOME!


(oh and also this is a picture of clouds and things)

title: ZOMGDESKTOP
description:
Two 19" 1280x1024 monitors, one 17" 1024x768, one 22" 1680x1050

The leftmost monitor is used for instant messaging, so I need only glance to my left to read my most recent message. The middle left one is dedicated to WinAmp, its my DJ center (I've always got music playing, except for when i have videos playing on my...) Right middle monitor, smaller than all the rest but very nice, I use it for videos (movies, tv-shows, etc) and the desktop area is used for future blog ideas

Which brings me to the rightmost monitor, which is the biggest and best of all of them. Its my primary monitor and where everything important happens

Note that the wallpapers are temporary, I have a program that changes them every few minutes from a (ever growing) folder of wallpapers that has like 2,000+ in it.

I LUFF MAH COMPUTER

title: Trigger
description:
This is my very first camera. It was a handmedown from my dad.

Lots of good memories:
Cruses to Mexico
Buying film in Mexico
Seeing Washington DC
Buying film in Washington DC
Recreating the past in Colonial Williamsburg
Buying film in Colonial Williamsburg
Mission trips to Equator
Buying film in Equator
Houseboating with church groups
Not being able to find film anywhere (and not getting any pictures)

...yeah I hate film
That and having to focus manually
Though having the dozen or so lenses my dad passed down to me was pretty convenient (lenses are expensive )
